What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic definitions in finite group representation theory, character theory, induced representations, Frobenius reciprocity, Mackey's irreducibility criterion, the group algebra and representations of Sn, basic definitions in representations of associative algebras, semisimple representations, representations of matrix algebras, Jacobson density theorem, semisimple algebras, Jordan-Holder decomposition.

The course teaches representation theory starting with representations of finite groups and later going into representations of algebras. We covered most of the material in the first few chapters of Fulton and Harris and Etingof et al.
Some representation of groups and algebras.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Qiu is a very understanding instructor and was always willing to adapt to student needs. The course content was very interesting, and it was very helpful to have textbooks to follow along. Homework and exams were also fair and helpful. 

Weaknesses: Lectures felt a little bit disorganized towards the end of the course. It was also a bit weird to me that we never talked about tensor products.

The clarity of explanation could have been better. I often felt confused and the instructor could have improved his handwriting. I also felt the midterm was slightly unfair given that one of the problems was impossible to solve. In terms of strengths, I would say the instructor is helpful during office hours and the project allows a lot of freedom to explore an area of interest.

It was never made clear why represetation theory is important. The course was very definition and computation driven, but there wasn't much motivation for what we were doing. It made it kind of hard to engage with the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am grateful for the instructor for uploading lecture notes onto Canvas, but I feel that they were sometimes illegible and often had omissions. Despite this, I still feel that I was able to learn the difficult material well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Representation theory is a fascinating area of math.

If you are interested in representation theory or algebra in general, then you should take this class. Many of the difficulties of this cannot be avoided due to the abstract nature of the material. I feel like I came away from the course with a solid understanding of the fundamentals of representation theory in addition to exposure to more advanced topics. If you are taking this class, be prepared to study some of the material from the textbook though. It often takes multiple tries to understand the material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
